greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Last nonzero decimal digit of (10^n)!.
comment: Except for n = 1, a(n) is also the last nonzero digit of(2^n)!. See the third Bomfim link. - _Washington Bomfim_, Jan 04 2011
link: W. Bomfim, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
W. Bomfim, An algorithm to find the last nonzero digit of n!
W. Bomfim, A property of the last non-zero digit of factorials
mathematica: f[n_] := Mod[6Times @@ (Rest[FoldList[{ 1 + #1[[1]], #2!2^(#1[[1]]#2)} &, {0, 0}, Reverse[IntegerDigits[n, 5]]]]), 10][[2]]; f[0] = 1; Table[ f[10^n], {n, 0, 104}]] (* _Jacob A. Siehler_ *)
program: (Sage) A173670 = lambda n: A008904(10**n)  # _D. S. McNeil_, Dec 14 2010
(PARI)\\ L is the list of the N digits of 2^n in base 5. \\     L[1] = a_0 ,..., L[N] = a_(N-1).
while(x, n=floor(n/5); r=x-5*n; listput(L, r); x=n;);
xref: Cf. A008904, final nonzero digit of n!.
Cf. A055476, Powers of ten written in base 5.
Cf. A053824, Sum of digits of n written in base 5.
results.author: _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Nov 24 2010
